Graphic abstract Fe-Ni hetero-diatomic pairing catalyst readily boosts the liquid-solid conversion kinetics of lithium sulfide via the effective d-p orbital hybridization between transition metal atoms and sulfur species, realizing high-rate performance Li−S batteries. An emerging practice in the realm of Li-S batteries lies in the employment of single-atom catalysts (SACs) as effective mediators to promote polysulfide conversion, but monometallic SACs affording isolated geometric dispersion and sole electronic configuration limit the catalytic benefits and curtail the cell performance. Here, we propose a class of dual-atom catalytic moieties comprising hetero- or homo-atomic pairs anchored on N-doped graphene (NG) to unlock the liquid–solid redox puzzle of sulfur, readily realizing Li-S full cell under high-rate-charging conditions. As for Fe-Ni-NG, in-depth experimental and theoretical analysis reveal that the hetero-atomic orbital coupling leads to altered energy levels, unique electronic structures, and varied Fe oxidation states in comparison with homo-atomic structures (Fe-Fe-NG or Ni-Ni-NG). This would weaken the bonding energy of polysulfide intermediates and thus enable facile electrochemical kinetics to gain rapid liquid-solid Li2S4 ↔ Li2S conversion. Encouragingly, a Li-S battery based on the S@Fe-Ni-NG cathode demonstrates unprecedented fast-charging capability, documenting impressive rate performance (542.7 mA h g−1 at 10.0 C) and favorable cyclic stability (a capacity decay of 0.016% per cycle over 3000 cycles at 10.0 C). This finding offers insights to the rational design and application of dual-atom mediators for Li-S batteries. Keywords Li–S batteries Reaction kinetics Dual-atom Rate-determining step High-rate performance 1 Introduction Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery is regarded as one of the most appealing energy storage technologies owing to its high energy density (2600 W h kg−1), advanced theoretical capacity (1675 mA h g−1) and sulfur affordability [1–4]. Nevertheless, its practical application is still plagued by daunting challenges, including the insulating nature of sulfur and its discharge product Li2S2/Li2S, the large volumetric fluctuation during discharge/charge, as well as the lithium polysulfide (LiPS) shuttling [5–10]. These would inevitably limit the sulfur utilization and cause rapid capacity attenuation. Recent years have witnessed the development of effective maneuvers pertaining to accelerating electrocatalytic conversion and mitigating polysulfide accumulation in addressing these issues, wherein the rational design of electrocatalytic mediators serves as the key [11–17]. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have attracted a burgeoning attention because of their impressive catalytic activity and maximized atom availability [18–23]. Meanwhile, transition metal (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, W, etc.) with 3d unoccupied orbitals enable the accommodation of foreign electrons to reduce the bonding strength between LiPS intermediates, expecting to catalyze the sulfur reduction process [24–29]. A multitude of latest studies have demonstrated that transition metal SACs can expedite polysulfide conversion when functioning as sulfur hosts and/or separator modificators [30–32]. In this sense, strategies including the adjustment of metal center, coordination number, coordination atom, synergistic species and supporting substrate of SACs have been put forward to optimizing the geometry/chemistry of the electrocatalysts toward boosted Li–S chemistry (Fig. 1 a). Nonetheless, there are still thorny issues on the applications of SACs in Li–S realm [33]. As for a typical SAC, a simple monometallic motif might possess high activity/selectivity for elementary process but not be necessarily sufficient for driving multi-step reactions involving multiple electron transfer. For instance, the selective catalytic effect of monometallic SACs toward specific reaction steps in sulfur reduction reaction (SRR) is not overwhelming owing to the structural limitation. In addition, the metal atom loading of SACs used for sulfur electrochemistry is generally less than 3 wt%, such a low distribution density of active sites would seriously affect the catalytic conversion efficiency of LiPSs. It is therefore urgent to design SAC electrocatalysts harnessing polynary metal centers for Li–S batteries. Dual-atom catalyst (DAC) has recently emerged as a new frontier in the field of heterogeneous catalysis [34–36]. DACs provide more opportunity to tune the d-band center for metals through electron orbital interactions as compared to SACs, thus anticipating to optimize the adsorption strength of LiPS intermediates at the active sites [37–39]. The synergy between adjacent metal centers is also likely to contribute to high catalytic activity, selectivity and stability [40,41]. In addition, DACs with more accessible metal loadings could improve holistic catalytic performance. However, the precise control over metal pairs (hetero-atomic pairs and homo-atomic pairs) of DACs during the preparation stage is difficult to be realized. Equally importantly, the structure-mechanism-performance relationship with respect to employing DACs for LiPS conversion remains to be established. In this study, we report a precise fabrication of high loaded (5.5 wt%) dual-atom moiety consisting of Fe-Ni hetero-diatomic pairs anchored on N-doped graphene (NG) toward boosted sulfur redox kinetics for Li–S batteries (Fig. 1b). In comparison with Fe-Fe and Ni-Ni homo-diatomic DAC counterparts, Fe-Ni hetero-atomic architecture exhibits a favorable electronic environment owing to the strong electronic coupling of d-d orbitals, thereby greatly enhancing the catalytic activity of DACs. Theoretical calculations imply that Fe-Ni-NG is conducive to expediting the phase-transition step in sulfur redox reactions. The effective d-p orbital hybridization between transition metal atoms and sulfur species helps anchor LiPSs/Li2S. Such a regulation markedly decreases the reaction barrier of the rate-determining step (i.e., Li2S2/Li2S precipitation), which accordingly enables much faster SRR kinetics. Benefiting from the efficient sulfur redox chemistry exerted by using the designed DAC, the thus-derived S@Fe-Ni-NG cathode attains outstanding electrochemical performances with a capacity retention rate of 63.6% over 1000 cycles at 0.2 C and a low capacity fading rate of 0.016% per cycle over 3000 cycles at 10.0 C. In further contexts, the assembled Li–S battery can achieve an areal capacity of 5.33 mA h cm−2 under a sulfur loading of 5.5 mg cm−2. The results shed light upon the fundamental understanding of expedited sulfur electrochemistry via atomically dispersed diatomic metal sites. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of Fe-Ni-NG, Fe-Fe-NG and Ni-Ni-NG L-alanine (3 g), melamine (3 g), and transition metal acetate [the molar ratio of iron (II) acetate/nickel (II) acetate = 1:1; ∼21 mg and 29 mg, respectively] were uniformly mixed for 30 min. Ethanol (10 mL), hydrochloric acid (3 mL) and the slurry were then added into the mortar, followed by grinding in a fume hood and dried in an oven at 60 °C for 12 h. The resulting powdery product was then subject to a heat treatment under flowing Ar in a tube furnace, where the temperature was raised to 600 °C at 3 °C min−1, held at 600 °C for 2 h, further ramped to 900 °C at 5 °C min−1 for 2 h, and finally cooled down to room temperature. The preparation recipes of Fe-Fe-NG and Ni-Ni-NG were identical except that only iron (II) acetate or nickel (II) acetate was employed as the metal source, respectively. 2.2 Characterizations The crystal structures of products were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) with a Bruker D8 Advance Diffractometer based on a Cu-K α radiation. Morphological micrographs and elemental maps were collected using a Hitachi SU8010 Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and a Titan Themis Cubed G2300 Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM). The aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field STEM (HAADF-STEM) images were taken by a TEM (FEI Titan3 G2 60–300) equipped with double spherical aberration correctors. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted on an Escalab 250Xi Spectrophotometer using a monochromatic Al K α X-ray source. SAC loading was analyzed by Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) using an Optima 8000 equipment (Perkin Elmer). The Fe and Ni K-edge X-ray absorption spectra (XAS) were obtained at beamline11B of Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility. The spectra were collected in the fluorescence mode at room temperature with the corresponding metal foils as references for energy calibration. The data were processed and fitted using the IFEFFIT-based Athena and Artemis programs. The spectra were calibrated, aligned, and normalized with the background removed. Thermogravimetry analysis (TGA) data were collected by TG/DTA7300. Raman spectra of the composites were obtained on HR Evolution (Horiba Jobin Yvon). 2.3 Fabrication of S@Fe-Ni-NG, S@Fe-Fe-NG and S@Ni-Ni-NG Sulfur composites were prepared by a melt-diffusion route. In detail, sulfur and host materials (Fe-Ni-NG, Fe-Fe-NG or Ni-Ni-NG) were mixed at a ratio of 4:1, which were grinded in a mortar for 30 min. The mixture was then put into a glass vessel and heated at 155 °C for 12 h to enable the diffusion of the sulfur into the host material. 2.4 Li2S6 symmetric cell assembly and measurement Li2S6 symmetric cells were assembled in a glovebox filled with Ar. Li2S6 solution (0.2 mol L–1) was prepared by mixing Li2S and sulfur with a molar ratio of 1:5 in the 1,2-Dimethoxyethane (DME)/1,3-dioxolane (DOL) solution containing LiTFSI (0.5 mol L–1) and LiNO3 (0.2 mol L–1). The Fe-Ni-NG/CP, Fe-Fe-NG/CP and Ni-Ni-NG/CP were prepared by dissolving Fe-Ni-NG (10 mg), Fe-Fe-NG (10 mg) or Ni-Ni-NG (10 mg) in ethanol (5 ml) and dropping them evenly on the carbon paper, which enabled a mass loading of 0.5 mg cm−2. The two identical electrodes were assembled into a standard CR2032 coin cell with a Celgard 2400 membrane served as the separator. The prepared Li2S6 solution (40 μL) was used as the electrolyte. CV tests of symmetric cells were performed at a scan rate of 0.5 and 50 mV s−1 with the voltage ranging from –1.0 to 1.0 V. 2.5 PITT measurement The Li2S8 solution (0.2 mol L–1) was prepared by dissolving Li2S and sulfur at a molar ratio of 1:7 in tetraglyme solution, followed by a vigorous stirring at 60 °C for 24 h. The coin cell for the PITT testing was assembled using Fe-Ni-NG/CP, Fe-Fe-NG/CP or Ni-Ni-NG/CP as the working electrode and Li foil as the counter electrode. 40 μL catholyte (0.2 mol L–1 Li2S8 dissolved in DOL/DME with 0.5 mol L–1 LiTFSI and 0.5 mol L–1 LiNO3) and 5 μL blank electrolyte was dropped onto the side of working and counter electrode, respectively. The PITT test was conducted on the PARSTAT 3000A electrochemical workstation. The cell was potentiostatically discharged from the open voltage to 1.9 V and then charged to 2.5 V with 50.0 mV per interval. 2.6 Electrochemical measurements The standard CR2032 coin cells were assembled using S@Fe-Ni-NG, S@Fe-Fe-NG or S@Ni-Ni-NG as the cathode, Li foil as the anode and Celgard 2400 membrane as the separator. The electrolyte contained 0.5 M LiTFSI in a solvent mixture of DOL and DME (1:1 in volume) with 0.5 M LiNO3. The E/S ratio used in the coin cells with typical sulfur loading was 15 µL mg−1. CV measurements at varied scan rates were carried out on the CHI660D electrochemical workstation. GCD tests and rate/cycling performance were conducted on a LAND battery testing system with a voltage range of 1.7–2.8 V (vs. Li/Li+). 2.7 In situ Raman measurements The electrode slurry was coated onto a punched Al mesh collector with a thickness of 0.05 mm and an inner aperture size of 0.5 mm × 1.0 mm, serving as the electrode. An electrochemical reaction cell was assembled for the battery, equipped with a quartz glass window to allow laser focusing on the electrolyte and electrode regions. The electrochemical reaction cell was connected to an electrochemical workstation for constant current charge/discharge curve recording, while Raman spectroscopy was employed to monitor the real-time diffusion of LiPSs from the electrode surface into the solution in the electrolyte region of the Al mesh. 2.8 Theoretical simulation All the calculations were carried out by the spin-polarized density functional theory, executed by Vienna Ab initio Simulation Packages with projector augmented wave pseudopotential [42,43]. The electronic exchange–correlation interactions were handled by GGA-PBE functional [44]. Van der Waals correction of Grimme scheme (D3) was applied to depict the dispersion interactions between adsorbates and substrates [45]. The kinetic energy cutoff with plane wave basis set was 400 eV. A (6 × 6) graphene supercell with the vacuum layer of 15 Å was constructed for the polysulfides adsorption. The first-Brillouin zone integrations were used by 3 × 3 × 1 and 5 × 5 × 1 k-point mesh for geometrical optimizations and static simulations, respectively. All the structures were optimized until the total energy and residual force per atom were less than 10−5 eV and 0.02 eV Å−1, respectively. Furthermore, the charge analysis with the framework of Bader and density of states was simulated in detail [46]. The crystal orbital Hamilton populations (COHPs) were performed to bond analysis using the Local-orbital basis suite towards electronic-structure reconstruction (LOBSTER) software [47]. To describe the conversion of polysulfides for the soluble Li2S4 to the solid Li2S2 species on the substrates, the reaction energy was calculated using the energy difference between final and initial states. The binding energy of polysulfides was simulated by the formula: E b = E total – E surf – E PS, where E total and E surf are the total energy with and without the polysulfides, respectively. E PS is the energy of polysulfides. The more negative value indicates stronger binding strength. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 2 (a) schematically illustrates the synthetic route of hetero-diatomic Fe-Ni-NG. The dual-atom moiety was prepared by a facile C3N4 self-templating method, the key of which lies in the target trapping of bimetallic ions in the C3N4 skeleton formed at 600 °C, followed by the production of dual-atom anchored within the N6 enclosure at an elevated temperature of 900 °C. Owing to the high surface energy of N defects, metal atoms preferentially coordinate with them. The C3N4 skeleton is able to “enclose” two metal atoms via its N6 configuration, thus enabling the formation of a stable saturated M−M'-N6 state. Note that no acid leaching treatment was required to generate Fe-Ni-NG. ICP-OES measurement revealed that Fe and Ni content in the Fe-Ni-NG respectively reaches 2.28 and 3.26 wt% (Table S1), surpassing a multitude of previously reported dual-atom species. The morphology of the as-prepared Fe-Ni-NG was inspected by electron microscopy. It is evident that Fe-Ni-NG exhibits porous lamellar architecture (Fig. S1). The structural details of Fe-Ni-NG could be further reflected by TEM observation, showcasing a two-dimensional carbon crumpled structure without metal clusters (Fig. 2b and inset). Homo-diatomic Fe-Fe-NG and Ni-Ni-NG also show analogous morphologies, as witnessed in Figs. S2 and S3. To probe the elemental information of the Fe-Ni-NG, scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) equipped with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was employed, presenting a homogeneous distribution of C, N, Fe and Ni (Fig. 2c and d; Fig. S4). The HAADF-STEM inspection further evidenced the Fe and Ni distributions at an atomic resolution. As displayed in Fig. 2(e), the identified bright spots correspond to isolated atoms because of the atomic number contrast. It is noticeable that the isolated atoms exist in the form of pairs (highlighted by red boxes), which could be considered as Fe-Ni dual-atom moieties. Similarly, a multitude of paired bright spots could also be observed in the HAADF-STEM images of Fe-Fe-NG and Ni-Ni-NG (Fig. S5). Typically, the Fe-Ni pairs are featured by a spatial distance of ∼0.25 nm (Fig. 2f), implying the possible presence of metal–metal (FeNi) bonds. Supplementary statistical analysis on the spatial distance of Fe-Ni pairs further shows an average value of 0.25 ± 0.03 nm (Fig. 2g). The phase and crystallographic features of Fe-Ni-NG, Fe-Fe-NG, Ni-Ni-NG and NG were analyzed by XRD. Two peaks located at ∼28° and ∼44° could be assigned to the (002) and (101) planes of graphitic carbon (Fig. S6) [48]. No diffraction peaks related to metal or metal compounds can be tracked. Raman spectra of all samples display typical G (1576 cm−1) and D (1362 cm−1) band of graphitic carbon, resulting from the sp 2-hybridized and defective lattice, respectively (Fig. S7). The sulfur content within the S@Fe-Ni-NG can reach 73.3 wt% throughout thermogravimetric analysis (Fig. S8). The surface chemistry of Fe-Ni-NG sample was revealed by XPS. Full-scan spectrum corroborates the presence of Fe and Ni elements (Fig. S9). As depicted in the C 1s spectrum, the signals at 284.8, 285.8, 288.7 and 292.3 eV are associated with CC, CN, CN and CO bonding, respectively. Similarly, there are also discernible signals of Fe and Ni elements in the full-scan spectra of Fe-Fe-NG and Ni-Ni-NG (Fig. S10). As for the N 1s spectra in Fig. 3 (a), all the three samples show the existence of pyridinic-N, metal −N, pyrrolic-N, quaternary-N and oxidized-N species [49]. In terms of the high-resolution XPS Ni 2p and Fe 2p spectra of Fe-Ni-NG (Fig. S11), the position of Ni 2p 3/2 peak (854.2 eV) remains similar to that of Ni-Ni-NG, whereas the Fe 2p 3/2 peak (710.3 eV) upshifts as compared to Fe-Fe-NG (709.4 eV), suggestive of higher oxidation state of Fe within the Fe-Ni-NG. X-ray absorption spectroscopy pertaining to X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) was used to further investigate the chemical state and coordination environment of Fe and Ni atoms in the dual-atom moiety. Fig. 3(b) displays the recorded Fe K-edge XANES spectra of the Fe-Ni-NG, Fe-Fe-NG, Fe foil and Fe2O3. The shift in the absorption edge (+1.2 eV) to a higher energy level for Fe-Ni-NG as compared to that of Fe-Fe-NG indicates a higher oxidation state of Fe atom in Fe-Ni-NG (Fig. 3b inset). The Ni K-edge XANES spectra of Fe-Ni-NG and Ni-Ni-NG almost coincide especially at the absorption edge (Fig. 3c and inset), which is consistent with the XPS results. Fig. 3(d and e) display the Fourier transform EXAFS (FT-EXAFS) profiles, with the corresponding k 2-weighted k-space spectra shown in Fig. S12. FT-EXAFS spectra of Fe for Fe-Ni-NG and Fe-Fe-NG show the predominant peak at 1.53 and 1.44 Å, respectively, which originate from the scattering of first-shell Fe–N path. The Fe-N bond length of Fe-Ni-NG is elongated as compared with that of Fe-Fe-NG, indicating the altered chemical state of Fe because of the coupling Ni atom within Fe–Ni coordination. Notably, the peak at ∼2.5 Å in Fe-Ni-NG (consistent with the HAADF-STEM observation) suggests the presence of Fe–Ni diatomic configuration. Moreover, FT-EXAFS spectra of Ni for Fe-Ni-NG and Ni-Ni-NG both show signals at 1.39 and 2.23 Å, corresponding to Ni–N and Ni–metal bond, respectively. In contrast, the difference of Ni–N scattering between Fe-Ni-NG and Ni-NG is small. The wavelet transform (WT) EXAFS analysis was also performed to identify metal–N and metal–metal path for Fe-Ni-NG, Fe-Fe-NG, and Ni-Ni-NG (Fig. 3f–i; Fig. S13) [50]. The contour plots for all these samples present a WT-maximum at 3.5 or 4.0 Å−1, implying that they are composed of atomically dispersed metal sites with metal–N configurations. In addition, the WT signals at 4.8 and 5.4 Å−1 are derived from Fe–metal and Ni–metal path, respectively. Although the metal–metal (Fe–Ni) path in Fe-Ni-NG is similar to that of NiNi bond in Ni Foil, it is significantly distinct from FeFe bond, indicating hetero-nuclear metal–metal interaction in Fe-Ni-NG. The WT signals at the Fe and Ni K edges were also compared with the FT-EXAFS results, confirming the existence of metal–N coordination in the metal–metal bond in Fe-Ni-NG. According to the fine characterization, the optimized molecular configuration of Fe-Ni-NG can be finally established (Fig. S14). The nucleation and dissociation of Li2S is deemed as a “rate-determining” step in the sulfur redox process, which could be ascribed to the “liquid ↔ solid” transfer delay and Li2S insulating property. To unravel the promotion effect of Fe-Ni-NG on bidirectional electrocatalysis, potentiostatic intermittent titration technique (PITT) was used to conduct quantitative analysis [51]. The coin cells used for testing were assembled based on active material loaded CP (anode), Li2S8 catholyte, and lithium foil (cathode). As for the Li2S nucleation, the assembled cell was first discharged from open-circuit potential to 2.25 V at 0.05 mV s−1 and then potentiostatically discharged from 2.25 to 1.9 V at 50 mV intervals. As for Li2S decomposition, the cell was potentiostatically charged from 2.2 to 2.35 V using the same interval pattern. Fig. 4 (a and b) present the PITT curves and corresponding current/capacity profiles. As shown in Fig. 4(a), a current bump at 2.00 V indicates that Li2S nucleation reactions occurred in all cells. It is found that Fe-Ni-NG/CP has the largest nucleation peak response and the earliest nucleation peak time as compared to Fe-Fe-NG/CP and Ni-Ni-NG/CP, which could be clearly witnessed in Fig. 4(b). The nucleation response time of Fe-Ni-NG/CP is 219.35 min, whereas the Fe-Fe-NG/CP and Ni-Ni-NG/CP request 220.68 and 220.51 min, respectively. Meanwhile, the deposition capacity of Fe-Ni-NG/CP reaches 318.4 mA h gs –1, which is much higher than that of Fe-Fe-NG/CP (268.86 mA h gs –1) and Ni-Ni-NG/CP (197.82 mA h gs –1). To analyze in detail the nucleation and dissociation of Li2S, the Tafel curves of the corresponding redox peaks were plotted. As depicted in Fig. 4(c), the Tafel slopes of S@Fe-Ni-NG, S@Fe-Fe-NG, and S@Ni-Ni-NG electrodes are derived to be 83.4, 122.1, and 142.6 mV dec–1, respectively. This implies that Fe-Ni-NG affords the advanced Li2S nucleation kinetics. During the solid–liquid conversion of S8, the Tafel slopes of the above three electrodes reach 60.3, 68.9, and 71.5 mV dec–1, respectively (Fig. S15). Similarly, Li2S oxidation of Fe-Ni-NG/CP cell occurs at a lower potential in comparison with Fe-Fe-NG/CP and Ni-Ni-NG/CP counterparts (Fig. 4d). As further shown in Fig. 4(e), the Fe-Ni-NG/CP cell harvests the shortest response time (494.85 min) and the largest Li2S dissolution capacity (300.1 mA h gs –1) among the three cells. The S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode again has the smallest Tafel slope (76.5 mV dec–1) in comparison with S@Fe-Fe-NG (102.2 mV dec–1) and S@Ni-Ni-NG (119.2 mV dec–1) counterparts in the sulfur oxidation reaction process (Fig. 4f). These results imply that the synergistic effect of hetero-diatomic moieties is in favor of expediting the bidirectional sulfur redox kinetics. To ulteriorly evaluate the electrocatalytic behavior of Fe-Ni-NG with respect to the sulfur redox reaction, a series of electro-kinetic tests were performed. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) profiles of the symmetric cells were collected in a 0.2 mol L–1 Li2S6-contained electrolyte at a scan rate of 0.5 mV s−1. As depicted in Fig. 4(g), all results show two pairs of redox peaks (a and b; c and d) [52]. Peak a implies the reduction of Li2S8 to Li2S6 and peak b reflects the reduction of Li2S6 to Li2S; the peak c and d represent the reversible oxidation process of Li2S to S8. Apparently, Fe-Ni-NG/CP presents sharper redox peaks and smaller voltage polarization as compared with the counterparts, indicative of enhanced kinetics for sulfur redox reactions. Similarly, the highest redox current response can be observed for Fe-Ni-NG/CP based symmetrical cell at a faster scan rate of 50 mV s−1 (Fig. S16). In addition, the magnitude of the shuttle current is evaluated by the current response signal in the cell. As shown in Fig. S17, the cell with Fe-Ni-NG host presents a lower current signal in comparison with the other cells based on Fe-Fe-NG and Ni-Ni-NG hosts, indicative of mitigated shuttle effect and hence advanced LiPS management. Meanwhile, in situ Raman spectroscopic probing on Li–S cell with an S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode was performed during the initial discharge/charge cycle (Fig. 4h and i) [53]. Fig. 4(h) displays the collected Raman spectra, where the dynamic changes of LiPS compositions within the electrolyte could be tracked, since the signals of polysulfide ions, including S8 2−, S6 2− and S3 2−, are typically shown in the range of 150 to 550 cm−1. These Raman profiles depict a gradual weakening of polysulfide signals during discharging, followed by continuous signal enhancement during the subsequent charging process, indicative of excellent reversibility of LiPS conversion (Fig. S18). To probe the LiPS capture ability of Fe-Ni-NG, 3.5 mmol L–1 Li2S4 solution was prepared for visualized adsorption tests (Fig. S19). The color of the Li2S4 solution with the addition of Fe-Ni-NG completely fades in 6 h, indicative of superior anchoring effect on LiPSs among three materials. To verify the LiPS adsorption essence of Fe-Ni-NG, the anchoring behavior for Li2S4 was analyzed by post-mortem XPS. As illustrated in Fig. S20(a), the S 2p spectrum upon the Li2S4 adsorption could be deconvoluted into four contributions at 161.5/162.3, 163.4/165, 167.8/168.6 and 169.2/170.4 eV, in response to the metal−sulfur (M−S), bridged sulfur (SB−SB), thiosulfate, and polythionate species, respectively [54]. The formation of M−S covalent bonds is owing to the d-p hybridization, which greatly promotes the redox process of LiPSs. As for the Li 1s spectrum, the peak at 56.6 eV could be assigned to the LiN bonding (Fig. S20b), suggesting strong chemical capture of the terminal Li atoms in Li2S4 by the N sites in Fe-Ni-NG. Such a bonding is also attributed to the electron transfer between the metallic moiety and connecting N atoms via Lewis acid–base interactions, enabling efficient Li-ion trapping. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed to decipher the electronic structures and catalytic mechanism of the DACs. The hetero-diatomic catalyst was constructed by using Fe and Ni diatomic pairs anchoring on the N-doped graphene, namely Fe-Ni-NG, in comparison with the homo-diatomic congeners, Fe-Fe-NG and Ni-Ni-NG. Bader charge color map in Fig. 5 (a) elucidates the disparity of charge between Fe and Ni atom within Fe-Ni-NG. Fe atom enables the transfer of more electrons (1.16) to N and Ni atom as compared to Fe-Fe-NG (0.99), and Ni atom possesses less positive charge with the number of 0.84 than Ni-Ni-NG with 0.86, indicating higher oxidation state of Fe center (Table S2). Moreover, projected density of states (PDOS) of 3d orbitals for Fe (Ni) center were accordingly simulated (Fig. 5b and c). Their d xz and d yz orbitals are obviously delocalized, suggesting conspicuous d-d orbital coupling of the diatomic pairs. Interestingly, the Fe-Ni pair not only renders the d z 2 orbital of Fe center crossing the Fermi level but also lowers the energy levels with respect to 3d orbitals of Ni site and p orbitals of N atom. This is in stark contrast to the scenarios of homo-diatomic Fe-Fe and Ni-Ni pairs, as shown in Fig. S21. The PDOS of Fe, Ni and N atoms in Fe-Ni-NG manifests electron transfer from Fe atom to N and Ni atom, mostly to p z orbital of N atoms throughout the orbital coupling. To further reveal the catalytic activity of hetero-diatomic pair in the sulfur reduction reaction, first-principles calculation was applied to probe the soluble Li2S6/Li2S4 to solid Li2S2/Li2S transformation process which is regarded as the rate-determining step for the contribution of electrochemical capacity. To effectively describe the conversion process from Li2S4 to Li2S2, the free energy change was calculated. As depicted in Fig. 5(d), Fe-Ni-NG enables lower reaction barrier of 0.32 eV in comparison with Fe-Fe-NG (0.41 eV) and Ni-Ni-NG (0.43 eV). The binding strength of Li2S4 and Li2S2 species was derived (Fig. 5e), with their adsorption configurations shown in Fig. S22 and S23. Fe-Ni-NG harvests stronger bond strength via Fe(Ni)–S and Li–N bonding as compared to those of homo-diatomic supports, indicating the enhanced capture ability of LiPSs. Crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) analysis of Fe(Ni)–S bond was performed, showcasing the (anti)-bonding states that are mainly contributed by the p z orbital of S atom and d z 2 orbital of Fe (Ni) atom (Fig. 5f and g). Fig. 5(h) manifests the integrated COHP (ICOHP) value, which can quantitatively depict the d-p orbital hybridization strength. Since a more negative ICOHP value represents a stronger metal–sulfur interaction, Fe-Ni-NG hetero-diatomic pair owns the strongest FeS bonding for Li2S2 and Li2S4 adsorption, which in response possesses the shortest FeS bonding length with 2.37 and 2.55 Å, respectively (Fig. 5i). The formation of LiN bond also plays a critical role in LiPS anchoring owing to the large difference in electronegativity between Li and N element, resulting in relatively short bond lengths within a range of 2.1–2.2 Å (Fig. S24). Upon identifying the electrocatalytic and theoretical advance of dual-atom moieties, electrochemical performances of typical Li–S coin cells were comprehensively evaluated based on Fe-Ni-NG, Fe-Fe-NG, and Ni-Ni-NG sulfur hosts. Fig. 6 (a) presents the CV curves collected for S@Fe-Ni-NG, S@Fe-Fe-NG and S@Ni-Ni-NG electrodes at 0.05 mV s−1. Two characteristic cathodic peaks appear at 2.3–2.4 (Peak i) and 1.9–2.1 V (Peak ii) during the discharge in the voltage window of 1.7–2.8 V, which can be respectively attributed to the formation of soluble LiPSs and insoluble Li2S. The anodic peak of the charging process lies within 2.3–2.6 V (Peak iii), representing the related reversible process. Note that the S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode shows a larger current response and lower voltage polarization as compared with the others, which originates from the favorable electrocatalytic activity of Fe-Ni-NG owing to the electronic coupling of Fe and Ni dual atoms. CV curves of the three electrodes under different scan rates from 0.1 to 0.5 mV s−1 were also collected. The S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode again displays the smallest polarization and peak position shifts as the scan rate increases (Fig. S25). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy profiles were further acquired to reflect the electrode interface dynamics (Fig. S26). Obviously, S@Fe-Ni-NG has the lowest charge-transfer resistance (14.1 Ω) in comparison with S@Fe-Fe-NG (18.7 Ω) and S@Ni-Ni-NG (28.9 Ω). S@Fe-Ni-NG also possesses a smaller internal resistance, suggestive of advanced electron transport efficiency in Li–S cells. In terms of galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) curves at 0.2C (1.0C = 1675 mA g−1), the two plateaus are related to the stepwise reduction of LiPSs (Fig. 6b), which is in good agreement with the CV results. The S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode displays the both largest high/low plateau discharge capacity values (Q H/Q L). Meanwhile, the lowest voltage gap (ΔV 1) provided by S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode suggests a kinetically favorable process for Li–S chemistry. The documented overpotential behaviors shown as the inset imply the markedly improved kinetics of S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode. Fig. 6(c) presents the rate capability evaluation of these three electrodes (at a sulfur loading of 1.2–1.5 mg cm−2). The S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode delivers reversible capacities of 1277.7, 1141.2, 991.8, 831.5, 723.2 and 562.0 mA h g−1 under varied rates at 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 3.0 and 5.0 C, which is superior to those of S@Fe-Fe-NG and S@Ni-Ni-NG under identical conditions (Fig. S27). Impressively, our S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode could sustain a performance testing at an elevated current density of 10.0C, enabling a capacity of 366.9 mA h g−1 at 10.0 C and still retaining 1167.6 mA h g−1 when switched back to 0.2 C (Fig. S28). Fig. 6(d) shows the cycling performances at 0.2 C. The S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode harvests an overwhelming capacity retention of 98.5% upon 100 cycles owing to its enhanced bidirectional sulfur conversions and restrained LiPS shuttling (Fig. S29). The cycled electrodes were further characterized by SEM (Fig. S30), where the S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode exhibited no significant signs of cracking or agglomeration. This indicates the structural robustness of the prepared electrode. It is worth-mentioning that these dual-atom mediators unprecedently enabled a longevous cycling at 0.2 C for 1000 cycles (Fig. S31). As a control, bare NG host was also evaluated (Fig. S32). Under the cycling condition of 0.2 C, the capacity retention rate of S@NG electrode declined to 66.5% after 100 cycles, which is apparently inferior to those of dual-atom mediated electrodes. In addition, the cycling performance of S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode at 1.0 C was investigated (Fig. S33), achieving a high initial capacity of 1090.3 mA h g−1 and a low capacity decay of 0.034% per cycle after 1000 cycles. Fig. S34 shows the time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (ToF-SIMS) depth profiles of S− secondary ions in cycled sulfur cathodes at 1.0 C after 500 cycles. Obviously, the cycled S@Fe-Ni-NG cathode exhibits the lowest intensity of the sulfur migration layer as compared to those of S@Fe-Fe-NG and S@Ni-Ni-NG counterparts, suggestive of mitigated LiPS shuttle effect. Meanwhile, S@Fe-Ni-NG cathode still possesses the lowest S− secondary ion intensity at deeper etching depths, verifying the advanced catalytic ability of Fe-Ni-NG [55]. Fig. S34(a and b) presents two-dimensional cross-section profiles with respect to sulfur element reconstructions of the cycled cathodes, which shows the thickness of the sulfur migration layer following a clear trend of S@Fe-Ni-NG (22 μm) < S@Fe-Fe-NG (29 μm) < S@Ni-Ni-NG (31 μm). Similarly, the signals of the Li− secondary ions with the cathodes were detected (Fig. S34c), displaying the identical distribution trend with those of S− secondary ions. Moreover, the cross-section profiles with respect to lithium element reconstructions again demonstrate that the S@Fe-Ni-NG cathode has the thinnest sulfur migration layer (Fig. S34d). These exhaustive characterization results collectively imply the enhanced LiPS management in the presence of Fe-Ni-NG hetero-diatomic moiety toward boosted Li–S chemistry [56]. At a current density of 3.0 C, the S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode still sustained a stable cycling with a capacity decay of 0.04% per cycle after 1000cycles (Fig. S35). Collectively, the holistic cycling performances of our S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode markedly outperform those of recently reported sulfur hosts mediated by a variety of SACs, demonstrating the conspicuous catalytic ability of dual-atom moiety in LiPS management (Fig. 6e; Table S3). To test the performance under more demanding conditions, the Li–S cell was even cycled at an ultrahigh current density of 10.0 C for 3000 cycles (at a lower sulfur loading of ∼1 mg cm−2). As shown in Fig. 6(f), the S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode delivers an outstanding initial capacity of 542.7 mA h g−1 and maintains 279.1 mA h g−1 after 3000 cycles with a negligible capacity decay of 0.016% per cycle, holding great promise for high-rate applications. More encouragingly, such a fascinating high-rate performance compares favorably with those from recently reported studies (Table S4). The electrochemical performances of the S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode under high sulfur loadings were further evaluated. At a sulfur loading of 3.0 mg cm−2, the cell delivers reversible capacities of 1084.1, 981.3, 853.4 and 687.9 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5 and 1.0 C, respectively, manifesting a good rate performance (Fig. S36). When the sulfur loading was increased to 5.5 mg cm−2, the S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode presents an initial areal capacity of 5.33 mA h cm−2 and maintains 4.81 mA h cm−2 after 100 cycles at 0.2 C (Fig. 6g). It is evident that the areal capacity of the Li–S cell is superior to that of commercial Li-ion batteries. For a given sulfur loading, reducing the electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio might help improve the energy density of Li–S batteries [57–59]. In this sense, the cell performance under an E/S ratio less than 5 µL mg−1 was tested at sulfur loadings of 4.0 and 5.0 mg cm−2 (Fig. S37). Taken together, our high-sulfur-loaded cell affording S@Fe-Ni-NG electrode could rival with the related counterparts (Table S5). More encouragingly, the cycling performance test conducted on pouch cell at 0.2 C revealed that a sustainable operation could be maintained throughout 100 consecutive cycles under a sulfur loading of 4.3 mg cm−2 (Fig. S38). Collectively, we have garnered the precise synthesis of Fe-Ni dual-atom moieties via a simple strategic route, where a carbonaceous substrate with six-membered nitrogen rings is firstly constructed, followed by the target anchor of bimetallic atomic species. In contrast to previously published studies on diatomic catalysts for Li–S batteries, we have investigated, for the first time, the essential disparity between hetero- and homo-diatomic sites in relating to their holistic impacts over Li–S catalysis [60–62]. Among them, Fe-Ni moiety triggers strengthened d-p metal-sulfur orbital as compared to the cases of Fe-Fe and Ni-Ni sites, thereby facilitating stronger LiPS conversion effects. Accordingly, the assembled Li–S batteries exhibit good cycling stability at elevated-sulfur-loading conditions. Such an impressive electrochemical performance based on engineered Fe-Ni hetero-diatomic mediators is also superior to other reported Li–S systems affording dual-atom catalysts. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have precisely fabricated Fe-Ni dual-atom moiety by tuning the metal centers, displaying robust electrocatalytic performance in promoting sulfur redox chemistry. The atomic coordination environments of homo- and hetero-atomic DACs are confirmed by XAS analysis, in which the d-d orbital coupling between Fe and Ni atoms greatly enhances the catalytic activity. Theoretical calculations and electrokinetic measurements indicate that Fe-Ni-NG with hetero-diatomic Fe-Ni site could effectively immobilize LiPSs and decrease the reaction barrier of the liquid–solid conversion process owing to the hybridization of the d-p orbital. Benefiting from the favorable electrocatalytic behavior of Fe-Ni-NG, the thus-derived S@Fe-Ni-NG cathode sustains a stable cycling operation with a low capacity decay rate of 0.016% over 3000 cycles at 10.0 C. Furthermore, Li–S batteries can harvest excellent cyclic stability under high sulfur loadings and low E/S ratio conditions, holding promise for practical applications. This work paves a revolutionized route toward designing atomic-scale electrocatalysts for Li–S batteries via the modulation of dual-atom metal centers. coredata.dc:description: An emerging practice in the realm of Li-S batteries lies in the employment of single-atom catalysts (SACs) as effective mediators to promote polysulfide conversion, but monometallic SACs affording isolated geometric dispersion and sole electronic configuration limit the catalytic benefits and curtail the cell performance. Here, we propose a class of dual-atom catalytic moieties comprising hetero- or homo-atomic pairs anchored on N-doped graphene (NG) to unlock the liquid–solid redox puzzle of sulfur, readily realizing Li-S full cell under high-rate-charging conditions. As for Fe-Ni-NG, in-depth experimental and theoretical analysis reveal that the hetero-atomic orbital coupling leads to altered energy levels, unique electronic structures, and varied Fe oxidation states in comparison with homo-atomic structures (Fe-Fe-NG or Ni-Ni-NG). This would weaken the bonding energy of polysulfide intermediates and thus enable facile electrochemical kinetics to gain rapid liquid-solid Li2S4 ↔ Li2S conversion. Encouragingly, a Li-S battery based on the S@Fe-Ni-NG cathode demonstrates unprecedented fast-charging capability, documenting impressive rate performance (542.7 mA h g−1 at 10.0 C) and favorable cyclic stability (a capacity decay of 0.016% per cycle over 3000 cycles at 10.0 C). This finding offers insights to the rational design and application of dual-atom mediators for Li-S batteries.
